Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "modify warning message on display package page when missing readme" (#9365) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

* Introduced new warning message on package display page when package is missing readme
* only display warning message to package authors
* added feature flag to this new warning

Before: 
![Screenshot 2023-01-31 140711](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/215915916-076f6854-e2da-48fb-8a73-6a8f8ddf11ed.png)
After: 
![Screenshot 2023-01-31 140647](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64443925/215915939-7573b301-73ad-4108-98c8-5b3a164070df.png)


Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/123

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[TFM] net6.0-windows7.0 compatibility added." (#9364) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Description
We use NuGet client sdk in order to create a compatibility matrix for displaying TFMs on nuget.org. Currently there is no knowledge on nuget client sdk on what net5+ platform version exists (like net6.0-windows7.0) and they are not computed.

## Changes
* net6.0-windows7.0 compatibility has been hardcoded with known values.
* This compatibility will only show if a package contains that specific TFM in their assets.

## Screenshots

![Before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/214958483-83ed5463-ce87-4a93-86e0-de2ceedfe872.png)

![After](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/214958491-6f98386b-02b2-4d79-b40c-baa369998355.png)

## Notes
* Why doesn't these PR cover all the other versions?
  * We don't know the exhaustive compatibility on platform versions. 
* For further improvements we will need to collaborate with NuGet client and dotnet sdk: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4730. 

Addresses: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9337

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Retrieve only listed versions of a package" (#12370) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet SDK

### The Elevator Pitch

I might be missing something here, but it doesn't seem that I can use the SDK to retrieve only listed versions of a package.

Using `FindPackageByIdResource.GetAllVersionsAsync` you can retrieve all versions of a package, which includes listed and unlisted versions.

That would be OK if there was a property on the returned list of `NuGetVersion` objects, that could be used to determine if the version is listed.  For example there's an `IsPrerelease` that can be used to determine which versions are pre-releases, and filter on that if you needed to.  However I don't see anything that can be used to distinguish listed and unlisted versions.



### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show a Visual Studio notification when a vulnerability is detected" (#12399) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

In addition to #12398, a notification should appear in Visual Studio's notification center with a link to the package manager UI to address issues.

The notification will let the user know what package in what project/solution is vulnerable or its plural equivalent. i.e. `Known security vulnerabilities have been detected in your project(s)/solution`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/215889414-0cf1c648-0149-4958-a223-5c25a575020e.png)


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show an infobar for any detected security vulnerabilities in a project or solution." (#12398) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

When a project or solution are loaded and NuGet restore detects any security vulnerability, Visual Studio should provide an embedded infobar mentioning one or more vulnerabilities has been detected and a link to go to the package manager UI to address them.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/215889142-30b86882-e1f6-4248-be44-d7e13a5e40ea.png)


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Client support for Package Vulnerability Audit (PVA)" (#8716) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: This issue tracks the client-side work for **phase 1** of feature [[Security] Flag vulnerable packages #8087](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8087).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Expose package vulnerabilities information in the PMUI" (#10981) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "PM UI versions drop-down should show vulnerability information" (#12279) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

When choosing which version to install in PM UI, it would be helpful if the drop down (on Search, Install, Update tabs), will show if a package is vulnerable, for example by adding a warning icon next to the version.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16807822/204671655-a70f3635-9f54-4b87-82d1-94bcd9fa171e.png)

Potentially aligning with the nuget.org view:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16807822/204671765-c2d60543-a951-4a85-ab01-a130a62b8205.png)
 

### Additional Context and Details

As we focus on showing vulnerability information in different parts of the VS UI, IMO this would help in making the experience consistent across the board.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Unstable] An error “A project with ID ‘XXXXXXX-XXXXXXX’ was not found” occurred when installing a package with PackageReference format into a Console App (.NET Framework 4.8.1)" (#12397) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Dev\6.6.0.15

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:   
1. Create a solution with multiple projects (3 in this example) in VS, a C# Console App (.NET Framework 7.0), a C# Console App (.NET Framework 4.8.1) and a C# Class Library (.NET Standard 2.1).   
2. Right-click the project “C# Console App (.NET Framework 4.8.1)” in Solution Explorer and select "Manage NuGet Packages…" menu item to open PM UI.   
3. Click settings button (top-right of right panel), check "Allow format selection on first package install" in General tab and click OK.                                         
4. Go to "Browse" tab, click a package (for example "Newtonsoft.Json") and click the “Install” button.  
5. Select the “PackageReference in project file” in “Choose NuGet Package Manager Format” dialog and click OK button.
6. Click the OK button in “Preview Changes” dialog. 
#### Expected:   
The package can be installed successfully.
#### Actual:   
An error “A project with ID ‘XXXXXXX-XXXXXXX’ was not found” occurred in the Error List window as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/215740367-04a6ca8e-7462-431d-b7e8-fa48b55de769.png)
#### Notes:
1. It is unstable. The repro rate is about 30%.
2. It happened in single project Console App (.NET Framework 4.8.1) too, but it seems easy to repro in multiple projects.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "An error “Failed to update binding redirects for [ProjectName].csproj: Exception has been thrown by the target of an invocation.” occurred when installing package EntityFramework " (#12396) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.15

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:  

1. Start a new instance of visual studio (Don’t open PMC while executing this test). 

2. Create a new C# Class Library (.NET Framework 4.8.1). 

3. Install “EntityFramework” package with packages.config format in PM UI. 

4. Check install logs in output window, and make sure it has executed init scripts while installing. 

#### Expected:  

No error occurs. 

#### Actual:  

An error “Failed to update binding redirects for [ProjectName].csproj: Exception has been thrown by the target of an invocation.” occurred as below screenshot.  
  
![MicrosoftTeams-image (7)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84695155/215727128-69bfac66-d84e-40ca-985a-f76b2a8338d0.png)

#### Note:  

1. The issue doesn’t repro when installing a package with Package Reference format. 


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] The “Install” button is clickable and package can be installed successfully even if the custom version drop-down box is empty. " (#12395) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.15

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:   

1. Create a C# Console App (.Net core) project.   
2. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select "Manage NuGet Packages…" menu item to open PM UI.   
3. Click settings button (top-right of right panel), check "Allow format selection on first package install" in General tab and click OK.                                         
4. Go to "Browse" tab and click a package (for example "Newtonsoft.Json").  

5. Click the "Version" drop-down box in the right panel. 

6. Delete the default version from the custom version drop-down box and click “Install” button. 

#### Expected:   

The “Install” button should be unclickable after step 6. 

#### Actual:   

The “Install” button is clickable and package is installed successfully when no version is typed in the custom version drop-down box as below record: 
![custom version](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84695155/215724755-d8134b8d-9298-491f-b19e-e92c1fc57b1d.gif)


### Verbose Logs

_No response_
